utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: So can you tell me a little bit about what brought you in here today?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah, I've noticed I've had this pretty bad cough for like the last couple of days. A little bit worried. Wanna talk to someone.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, so started two days ago.

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No about what day is it today? Today is Wednesday. It started on Sunday, Sunday. I noticed it getting really bad.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, so it got really bad. Then it was it was it still present but not as bad before that?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah I think I had like a bit of like a raspy cough on like Friday but Sunday it was when I started getting nervous about it.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK so almost a week, it sounds like. And what exactly changed on Sunday that you made it worse in your opinion?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: So Sunday I started bringing I noticed like little spots of red kind of the the gunk I was bringing up.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK.

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: And I kind of ignored it, but the next day they were still there. I started getting fever just in I felt off, you know.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK. OK, so that you first notice that on Sunday, were you bringing up sputum before that and it just didn't have these spots or did it, did that part just start on Sunday?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Sputum is kind of like the gunk up and bring it up? Yeah, it was. It's like this yellow custard, it’s got like well spots are red on it on Sunday.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and before that did you have like the yellow custard without red? Or it all started at once all kind of started?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: It all started at once to be honest.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Sorry, I know these are tricky questions, and you said that you've had some fevers. Can you tell me a little bit about that? When did that start?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: So that started, the Monday really is when I first started. I never took my temperature. I just felt hot. You know that's been going on pretty much until today.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, did you ever feel like you were really shaky?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah, I've been getting the chills, especially last two days.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK. So over this time you've had this cough, have you felt like you've had difficulty breathing?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Not really, I feel a little bit winded doing things. I used to do like I take the stairs up to my apartment, but I have just happened really trying to exert myself that's been taking it easy so I haven't really noticed being out of breath.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, so probably if you were to get up and do a lot of physical activity you would feel worse.

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah, I could, probably I can still take the two stairs up to my apartment, but after that I started to feel pretty crummy.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK. Is there anything else that you can think of that makes it feel worse?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Has anything helped it to feel better at all?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Bringing up gunk makes it feel better for a little while.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: So you kind of just clear it up and that feels a little bit better?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah, I haven't taken some Tylenol at home and that helps a little bit.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, have you felt a sore throat at the same time?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: After an awful lot of coughing, yeah, it starts to feel a little raw.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Have you had a runny nose?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah, bit of 1 back in the day, maybe a week ago, but that kind of gone away by now.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Have you felt any chest pain?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah. Yeah I got pain kinda on the right.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK. Have you ever have you ever had anything like this before?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No never. Actually Doc, you're saying something that makes it feel worse? Taking a deep breath makes it feel pretty bad.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and. I'm just going to circle back to this chest pain. You said you feel it on the right side. Is it always there or is it just when you take a deep breath or is it kind of on and off?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: It's kind of always there. It gets a little bit worse with coughing and when I take a pretty big deep breath.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Yeah, OK, but if you were just laying down, not coughing, is that pain there?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah yeah, specially notice over the last day,

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK.

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Kind of dull.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK. And have you had any weight loss recently?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, not really.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: K. Have you traveled anywhere recently?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Went to Sarnia. About a week back for work but.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, were you in contact with anyone that that was sick?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Nope, just been keeping to myself mostly.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, so in terms of your own medical history, do you have any chronic conditions that you see your family doctor for regularly?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah, he’s given me a pill for a cholesterol.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK. And do you know the names of any medications that you take?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Lipitor.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK is that the only one?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK. Have you ever had any surgeries?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh, my wisdom teeth out as a as a kid. 15 or so I think.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK. Do you have any allergies?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: I’m just going to ask you a few questions about your lifestyle and like do you live here in town?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah, I live here in town, got a girlfriend living in apartment.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, you live with your girlfriend,

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Do you have any pets?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Cat, yeah.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Do you do anything for work or are you retired?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah, I still work a consultant for the chemical plant, so West. Mainly in Sarnia.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: So have you had a lot of exposure to chemicals throughout your career?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Now they've always been pretty good for keeping us safe. I'm on the engineering side of things, so I don't really work too much in the plant directly. You know,

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK. Here, well, do you drink alcohol?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Once in a blue moon.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Do you smoke?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: How much would you say that you smoke?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Got a pack a day.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Long is that been going on for?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Geez, must have picked it up when I was 15.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK. Do you use any other substances?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Like drugs?

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Yeah, cannabis or any other recreational drugs.

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Smoke the odd joint from time to time, but haven't in years now.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Do you have any family history of any respiratory illnesses?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Respiratory illness, like lungs?

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Yeah, exactly.

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Think my grandpa died of lung cancer, actually he was a pretty big smoker too though.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK. OK, well thank you for sharing all of that with me, so I'm going to go over this with the physician I’m working with and we should be back shortly together to talk to you about the next steps.

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Thank you kindly.

utterances.speaker: control
utterances.text: Add differential diagnosis
